clean_text: The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), CISA, and NSA are releasing this joint Cybersecurity Advisory to inform blue teams about a fictional APT-99 campaign observed in training simulations. APT-99 actors likely conduct reconnaissance by gathering domain properties and monitoring for unencrypted Wi-Fi networks to identify potential entry points. System logs from a fictional company, CloudTech Inc., show normal authentication attempts during this phase, but no tagged activity. In the execution phase, the adversary employed vSphere Web Services SDK to abuse ESXi administration commands for persistence across guest VMs while simultaneously exploiting ptrace system calls to hijack the VDSO and execute malicious code. Network traffic analysis revealed tampering with the SSL/TLS driver to weaken encryption, downgrading protocols to weaker versions, though unrelated firewall alerts were logged for routine updates. For command and control, APT-99 leveraged the SMB protocol as an application layer protocol, hiding malicious traffic within normal file server activity, and used character insertion obfuscation to make scripts appear to contain Chinese characters. In the impact phase, the malware terminated the virtual machine hosting C2 infrastructure to delete the cloud instance and erase forensic traces, with backup systems reporting standard maintenance events that are not tagged.

llm_raw_response.title: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory: Fictional APT Campaign Targeting Hybrid Cloud Environments
llm_raw_response.summary: This advisory details a simulated campaign by a fictional advanced persistent threat (APT) group, designated as APT-99, targeting organizations with hybrid cloud infrastructures. The campaign involves reconnaissance, exploitation of virtualization platforms, and obfuscated command and control (C2) to weaken encryption and erase forensic traces. Blue teams should use this report for training to identify and mitigate similar tactics.
